reasoning: The critique targets a key argumentative move in the essay’s Section 3: using decision-theoretic/moral-uncertainty pathologies (dominance violations, pro-extinction tendencies, “fanaticism”) to argue that the remaining plausible views are mostly fussy, hence “no easy eutopia.” If this objection worked, it would substantially weaken the systematic case that easygoing views are implausible. However, it is not fully central to the whole essay because (i) Section 2’s core “fragility/product-of-factors” intuition can stand without committing to any particular intertheoretic aggregation/normalization scheme, and (ii) the essay already flags these pathologies as thorny rather than treating them as decisive. Strength is moderate-low: the critique is more of a methodological suspicion than an object-level refutation; it doesn’t show that alternative representational/aggregation choices would systematically vindicate easygoingness, nor that the essay’s specific complaints about easygoing bounded views (e.g., scale-tipping) fail on their own terms. Relevance is high because Forethought explicitly treats moral uncertainty, vNM-style cardinalization, and EV-style aggregation as decision-relevant, live issues (Tier 3 / cross-tier interaction with their EV decomposition). Overall the critique raises a real concern but doesn’t yet deliver a strong knockout without further argument and concrete alternative machinery.
title: "The Boomerang Effect of Pro-Extinction Implications"
